verses.text: Now Sarai, Abram’s wife, had borne him no children. She had an Egyptian servant whose name was Hagar.
verses.comment: This introduces Hagar, who comes from Egypt, connecting back to Abram and Sarai's earlier journey there (Gen 12:16). The barrenness of Sarai sets the stage for God’s work through unexpected means.

verses.text: Sarai said to Abram, 'Behold now, the Lord has prevented me from bearing children. Go in to my servant; perhaps I shall obtain children by her.' And Abram listened to the voice of Sarai.
verses.comment: The phrase 'listened to the voice of Sarai' mirrors the language of Adam listening to Eve (Gen 3:17). Sarai’s plan reflects ancient customs (see Gen 30:3 with Rachel), but the narrative subtly shows human attempts versus trusting God’s timing.

verses.text: So after Abram had lived ten years in the land of Canaan, Sarai, Abram’s wife, took Hagar the Egyptian, her servant, and gave her to Abram her husband as a wife.
verses.comment: Ten years highlights a period of testing. Giving Hagar 'as a wife' (not merely a concubine) emphasizes the legitimacy of offspring by ancient standards, though it departs from God’s intended design for marriage (cf. Gen 2:24, Matt 19:4-6).

verses.text: And he went in to Hagar, and she conceived. And when she saw that she had conceived, she looked with contempt on her mistress.
verses.comment: Hagar’s conception introduces tension and reverses her role with Sarai. Similar family struggles repeat in Genesis (see Gen 30:4–5 with Rachel and Bilhah), foreshadowing ongoing conflict and the consequences of stepping outside God’s direct promise.

verses.text: And Sarai said to Abram, 'May the wrong done to me be on you! I gave my servant to your embrace, and when she saw that she had conceived, she looked on me with contempt. May the Lord judge between you and me!'
verses.comment: Sarai expresses distress and appeals to the Lord for judgment. This invocation for God as arbiter reiterates the importance of entrusting one’s sufferings and disputes to divine justice, anticipating the role of intercession and suffering in redemptive history.

verses.text: But Abram said to Sarai, 'Behold, your servant is in your hand; do to her as you see fit.' Then Sarai dealt harshly with her, and she fled from her.
verses.comment: Abram relinquishes responsibility, giving Sarai authority over Hagar. The episode shows the brokenness resulting from human decisions not fully aligned with God’s plan, paralleling later expulsion themes (Gen 21:10).

verses.text: The angel of the Lord found her by a spring of water in the wilderness, the spring on the way to Shur.
verses.comment: This is the first appearance of 'the Angel of the Lord' (often understood in Christian theology to be a pre-incarnate manifestation of Christ; cf. Exod. 3:2). God seeks out the oppressed, signaling His concern for all nations and pointing to later themes of redemption and inclusion.

verses.text: And he said, 'Hagar, servant of Sarai, where have you come from and where are you going?' She said, 'I am fleeing from my mistress Sarai.'
verses.comment: God’s question echoes His address to Adam and Eve after the Fall (Gen 3:9). This divine dialogue invites honest self-examination, a pattern found in the lives of saints and those called into relationship with God.

verses.text: The angel of the Lord said to her, 'Return to your mistress and submit yourself under her hand.'
verses.comment: Hagar is directed to return and submit—an act of humility and obedience that precedes divine intervention. This call to faithful obedience even amid suffering is echoed throughout salvation history and in the lives of the faithful when enduring hardships for a greater purpose.

verses.text: The angel of the Lord also said to her, 'I will surely multiply your offspring so that they cannot be numbered for multitude.'
verses.comment: The promise given to Hagar parallels God’s promise to Abraham. God’s blessing extends beyond the chosen line, prefiguring the opening of salvation to all peoples (cf. Isa 56:7, Acts 10:34-35), a major later theme in Scripture.

verses.text: And the angel of the Lord said to her, 'Behold, you are pregnant and shall bear a son. You shall call his name Ishmael, because the Lord has heard your affliction.'
verses.comment: 'Ishmael' means 'God hears.' The naming reflects God’s ongoing concern and response to those in distress—a recurring motif that climaxes in the coming of the Messiah, who enters into the world’s pain. The role of naming in divine revelation continues throughout Scripture.

verses.text: He shall be a wild donkey of a man, his hand against everyone and everyone’s hand against him, and he shall dwell over against all his brothers.'
verses.comment: The prophecy concerning Ishmael foreshadows ongoing conflict but also a distinct place among Abraham’s descendants. This underscores God’s sovereignty over history and the fulfillment of His word across generations.

verses.text: So she called the name of the Lord who spoke to her, 'You are a God of seeing,' for she said, 'Have I even here seen him who sees me?'
verses.comment: This is the only instance in Genesis where a person gives a name to the Lord. 'God of seeing' or 'El Roi' highlights God’s personal attention—a truth realized in the Incarnation, when God sees and enters into humanity’s experience (cf. John 1:14).

verses.text: Therefore the well was called Beer-lahai-roi; it lies between Kadesh and Bered.
verses.comment: Beer-lahai-roi means 'Well of the Living One who sees me.' This becomes a sacred location, reminding future generations of God’s provision and attentive care—a motif that reemerges around sacred places and sacramentals in the wider biblical faith.

verses.text: And Hagar bore Abram a son, and Abram called the name of his son, whom Hagar bore, Ishmael.
verses.comment: Abram accepts Hagar’s son by naming him Ishmael, fulfilling the word of the Lord. The significance of naming in the biblical narrative points to mission and identity—concepts foundational to the ongoing story of divine election.

verses.text: Abram was eighty-six years old when Hagar bore Ishmael to Abram.
verses.comment: Abram’s age highlights the continued wait for God’s ultimate promise through Sarah. Faith requires trust in God’s timing and ways, which are often unexpected, prefiguring how fulfillment comes later through divine initiative.
